title: ASX to rise, S&P 500 nears record
text:
"Investors are pricing in one more 25bp rate cut this year, and between one and two rate reductions in 2020," Mr Ashworth said in a note.

Still, Mr Ashworth sees reason for optimism: "The Fed’s rate cuts and the growing optimism on US-China trade relations has un-inverted the yield curve, with the 10-year Treasury yield rising back above the yield on 3-month bills. That implies that the risks of a recession over the coming year, while still elevated, are fading.

"The growing hope of a favourable resolution of the trade war has helped push the S &P 500 back close to a record high. It has also contributed to a 1% or so weakening in the trade-weighted dollar."

The spot price of iron ore, as reported by Fastmarkets MB, slid another 1.1% overnight to $US85.40 a tonne; it's now tumbled 8.5% so far this month and is now at its lowest since the end of August.

Atlassian continued to lose altitude, sliding another 0.5% and extending the retreat from mid August to 21% as investors rethink the outlook for the software sector in a slowing growth environment, according to Morgan Stanley.

No local data

From today's Financial Review

Alarm at ASX's blockchain armageddon: As the ASX moves towards the pointy end of replacing Australia’s equity clearing and settlement system it is suddenly dawning on a range of market participants that their businesses could disappear.

Super funds pile into tech as AirTree closes $275m fund: One of the country's best known VCs has closed a big new fund to target fast growing companies, saying institutional investors are now much more eager to join the fray.

Aaron Hornlimann checks in to the Young Rich List: The 32-year-old's Elenium Automation builds check-in kiosks and luggage recognition machines used by 50 airlines.

United States

Advertisement

S&P 500 closes in on record high: Trade-sensitive technology stocks rose 1.1 per cent, adding the most to the benchmark index.

Morgan Stanley on earnings season: "Third quarter earnings season has gotten off to a mixed start. Earnings growth estimates for the index are tracking at -5% but companies have been beating estimates by approximately as much. Six of eleven sectors are expected to see negative earnings growth and nearly all are expected to have negative operating leverage."

MS also said based on the current level of earnings revision breadth, the S &P 500 should be trading closer to flat on a year-over-year basis rather than the +6% y/y it closed at on Friday.

Boeing Co may have to book billions of dollars in additional charges related to its grounded 737 MAX jets, brokerages said on Monday, following reports that call into question the timing of the aircraft's return to service.

Credit Suisse and UBS downgraded the stock after reports on Friday showed internal messages between two Boeing employees stating that the plane's anti-stall system behaved erratically during testing before the aircraft entered service.

The new revelations pose fresh challenges for Boeing, which is reeling under pressure after two fatal crashes forced the company to ground the planes and book billions of dollars in losses.

Capital Economics: "The strike at GM is dragging into its sixth week, pending approval of an agreement to end the dispute. This means that auto production will probably remain a drag for a while longer. The October Employment Report, due next week, is also likely to be weak."

Europe

Advertisement

Boris Johnson denied fresh parliamentary Brexit vote: The British PM is again on his back foot after Speaker John Bercow invoked a rule that the same motion can't be voted on twice.

UK midcaps closed the session with modest gains on Monday on hopes that a no-deal Brexit will be avoided, even though uncertainties persisted as lawmakers forced Prime Minister Boris Johnson to seek another extension from the European Union.

The domestically focused FTSE 250 added 0.4% on Monday, while the exporter-heavy FTSE 100 edged 0.2% higher, lagging its European counterpart as the pound strengthened.

A 9% plunge in medical device maker Smith+Nephew after its CEO departed also capped gains.

The FTSE 250 has gained nearly 4% over the last two weeks, handily outperforming blue chips, as investors had bet that a long drawn out Brexit process could be nearing its end as Johnson chased a withdrawal agreement with the EU.

The pan-European STOXX 600 index ended the session 0.6% higher.

Germany's DAX jumped 0.9%, leading gains among major regional indexes.

Business software group SAP's shares gained 2.5% after saying it had reached a three-year deal with Microsoft to help its enterprise customers move their business processes into the cloud. The company also reiterated its forecast for the year and through to 2023.

Advertisement

German payments company Wirecard jumped 6% on news the firm was hiring KPMG to conduct an independent audit to address allegations in the Financial Times that its finance team had sought to inflate its reported sales and profits.

Investors will be scanning third-quarter report cards from European firms to assess their health amid lingering Brexit and trade uncertainties. UK-listed RBS and Barclays are scheduled to report this week, kicking off bank earnings.

Companies listed in STOXX 600 are expected to report a 3.7% drop in third-quarter earnings, worse than the 3% fall expected a week ago, according to Refinitiv IBES data.

Asia

Hong Kong stocks closed flat on Monday, amid concerns around political protests in the city, while investors also waited for more details on the potential Sino-US trade deal.

The Hang Seng index was unchanged at 26,725.68, while the China Enterprises Index was also flat at 10,543.41.

The blue-chip CSI300 index rose 0.3%, to 3880.84, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.1% to 2939.62.

China on Monday unexpectedly kept unchanged its new benchmark lending rate, though analysts argued the decision does not point to an end to the downward adjustment in the loan prime rate (LPR).

Advertisement

"Looking ahead, we still see each monthly LPR re-set as providing an opportunity for a baby-step reduction," said Frances Cheung, head of Asia macro strategy at Westpac in Singapore.

Overall China's economy in the first three quarters remained relatively stable, showing strong resilience, and there would be a positive impact from the Sino-US trade talks if they move towards solving the problem, Guosen Securities noted in a report.

Currencies

Lowe, Frydenberg are wrong: rates to be cut again: Leading economists expect another rate cut in the new year despite the RBA downplaying the need for more easing and Treasurer Josh Frydenberg talking up global growth.

The US dollar was crawling toward its worst month since January 2018 as intermittent waves of Brexit optimism pushed the pound to a 5-1/2 month high and kept the euro’s bumper October intact.

Although Prime Minister Boris Johnson this weekend was forced by his opponents to send a letter to Brussels seeking a delay to Britain’s departure from the European Union as UK lawmakers delayed a vote on a reworked Brexit deal, the currency market reflected tentative hopes that it would eventually be passed. Johnson will again try to put his Brexit deal to a vote in parliament on Monday.

Against the US dollar, sterling was last up 0.1% in North American trade, having earlier broken above $US1.30 for the first time in 5-1/2 months. The euro was 0.18% higher against the US dollar having also been lifted by Brexit optimism this month by 2.23%.

The greenback - the dollar index - is down 2.1% this month against a basket of six rival currencies which, if it stays that way, would be its worst month since January 2018.

Advertisement

The New York Federal Reserve on Monday accepted $US58.15 billion in bids from primary dealers at a repurchase agreement (repo) operation, a move aimed at helping maintain the federal funds rate within the target range.

Monday’s amount was slightly bigger than the $US56.65 billion overnight repos awarded on Friday.

Commodities

Blue sky mines can come at a heavy cost: The lure of very big iron ore projects in Western Australia has proved costly for Japan, China and Australia Inc alike.

Copper prices rose to one-month highs as protests in major producer Chile fuelled concern about supplies and the prospect of easing trade tensions between China and the United States boosted sentiment.

Benchmark copper on the London Metal Exchange ended 0.4% up at $US5828 a tonne. Prices of the metal used in power and construction earlier touched a session high of $US5868.50.

"Some of it is a knee-jerk reaction to what's happening in Chile, but as far as we know copper production hasn't been affected," a trader said.

"Positive noises on resolving the US-China standoff helped, but the market is still worried about demand, particularly in China."

Advertisement

Chile is "at war" and the government will extend a state of emergency to more cities, President Sebastian Pinera said after at least seven people were killed in violent clashes and arson attacks over the weekend.

Chile's mining industry was running as normal despite the violent protests that have rocked the capital, Santiago, and other cities across the world's top copper producer, Mining Minister Baldo Prokurica said.

Union workers at BHP's Escondida copper mine will hold a day-long strike on Tuesday in a show of solidarity with protests in Chile.

Australian sharemarket

Shares in Australia's fast-charging technology companies were savaged on Monday as short-seller reports, regulatory risks and investors jittery about frothy valuations dumped shares in the highly fancied WAAAX stocks.

WiseTech, Afterpay Touch, Altium, Appen and Xero all ended the session in the red, with logistics software provider WiseTech slammed after research firm J Capital backed up last week's criticism of the $8.5 billion company by raising more concerns about its core software platform, saying the product was expensive and offered inferior service to customers.

WiseTech slumped 12 per cent, pacing the losses in the sector, while buy now, pay later provider Afterpay tumbled 3.3 per cent as investors were rattled by the Reserve Bank of Australia's review of the payments system.

Machine learning play Appen fell 4.3 per cent, printed circuit board provider Altium dropped 1.7 per cent and accounting software provider Xero shed 1.7 per cent.

Advertisement

The S &P/ASX 200 Index added 2.8 points, or 0.04 of a percentage point, to end Monday's trading session at 6652.2 points. The All Ordinaries Index was down 0.7 points, or 0.01 per cent, to lay at 6757.7 points.

Street Talk

Goldman Sachs cracks open Owens-Illinois bottles sale

Brookfield asks banks to help fund $2b Aveo bid

Fundies called to cornerstone Retail Zoo float at 15-times profit
description: Australian shares are set to open higher, bolstered by renewed hopes of a trade deal between the US and China.
